qas.question: When do football clubs still play friendlies?

answers.text: before the start of each season

qas.question: What type of football matches are non-competitive?
What do some friendlies change the rules to make unlimited?
What are some examples of friendly short football tournaments?

answers.text: the Emirates Cup, Teresa Herrera Trophy and the Amsterdam Tournament

qas.question: What do friendly short football tournaments have little of?

plausible_answers.text: before the start of each season

qas.question: It when went to football clubs not play Friendly's?
What type of football matches are considered to be competitive?
What allows teams to play older more experienced players?
What type of games have trophies and prestige attached to them?

context: Since the introduction of league football, most club sides play a number of friendlies <a0_0><b5_0>before the start of each season<b5_0/><a0_0/> (called pre-season <a1_0>friendlies<a1_0/>). <b6_0>Friendly football matches<b6_0/> are considered to be non-competitive and are only used to "warm up" players for a new season/competitive match. There is generally nothing competitive at stake and some rules may be changed or experimented with (such as <b7_0>unlimited <a2_0>substitutions<a2_0/>,<b7_0/> which allow teams to play younger, less experienced, players, and no cards). Although most <b8_0>friendlies<b8_0/> are simply one-off matches arranged by the clubs themselves, in which a certain amount is paid by the challenger club to the incumbent club, some teams do compete in short <b9_0>tournaments<b9_0/>, such as <a3_0>the Emirates Cup, Teresa Herrera Trophy and the Amsterdam Tournament<a3_0/>. Although these events may involve sponsorship deals and the awarding of a trophy and may even be broadcast on television, there is little <a4_0>prestige<a4_0/> attached to them.
